授業目的: Students can get a clear image of the revolutionary change in the world order by analyzing international political issues, with which Japan is confronting in today's multipolar world. This course will examine issues and agenda of the current Japanese foreign policy and discuss those issues with students. This will be useful to the students who wish to become diplomat or member of the international organizations as well as political and business leader.
到達目標: Students will get a clear understanding on what are the key problems of the foreign policy of Japan both in theory and practice, thus enabling them to discuss various issues of Japanese and world politics on a level equal to that of the business and professional people.

In this class we will be discussing the basic policy of Japanese diplomacy to cope with the most pressing issues with its neighbors, including how to cope with expanding China and destabilizing North Korea (DPRK) as well as how to manage good relations with difficult neighbor of South Korea. Japan has territorial issues with all its neighboring countries including Russia.
The settlement of World War II is not yet completed even today in Northeast Asia particularly with Russia and North Korea. How Japan should settle all those issues will be discussed.

Oct.15 "The way to an Asian Entente" (Japan's role in Asia). In the 1990's Japan proposed an idea of "East Asian community concept", however, it proved to be that such a regional integration process as the European Union (EU) was premature and unrealistic. 第5回:
Oct.22 "History and Diplomacy (1): Has Japan overcome the issues of the past?"
Japan still confronts with the problems of the history with its neighboring countries, particularly South Korea. The issues include so-called "comfort women" for Japanese soldiers, "wartime workers" from the Korean Peninsula. What is the actual situation of the dispute and what has the Japanese Government been doing to cope with these extremely sensitive issues during 75 years after the end of the Word War II? We would like to discuss this delicate issue with open and frank manner based on the facts. Power Points materials will be made available for deliberation on this issue before the class starts. Please visit the MOFA Japan Homepage: https://www.mofa.go.jp/policy/postwar/index.html
Students are recommended to read some related books in the University Library or search on the internet.
第6回:
Oct.29 "History and Diplomacy (2): Can Japan reconcile with its neighbors?" A comparison to Germany's case of overcoming its history. Germany has always been equated as a model country for Japan in overcoming the history issue, which had reconciled with the victim countries. Why was it possible ? What kind of reconciliation measures were taken by Germany? What are the reactions coming from the victim countries? Apology and forgiveness are crucial elements for a successful reconciliation process. We would like to discuss success and failure of the reconciliation process comparing Germany and Japan. PowerPoint materials will be made available for this class.

Read the following paper: "From Nazism to Never Again How Germany Came to Terms with Its Past ", Foreign Affairs, January/February 2018
Students are requested to read books or materials on Germany's case either at the University Library or through internet search.
第7回:
Nov.5 "Thinking of Japan's Security: The Japanese Constitution and the right to collective self-defense"
In this class we would like to examine how Japan has been trying to overcome its constitutional constraints, particularly the use of the right to collective self-defense in case of eminent threat to its security.
Since the end of the Cold War In 1989, Japan embarked on a new stage to proactively contribute to the maintenance of international peace and security through military and non-military means at its disposal. However, there are constitutional constraints, when it dispatches self-defense forces beyond its territory for the purpose of UN Peace Operations including UNPKO and other military activities to maintain peace. IN Japan, the issue of the right to collective self-defense
has always been argued in connection with the dispatch of the Self-Defense Forces outside of Japan. How Japan has overcome, not completely but to certain degree, this sensitive political issue in recent years, will be explained.

第8回:
Nov.12 "Geopolitical Importance of Europe to Japan: The possibilities and Limitations of EU (Brexit/Euro/Migration/Refugee/ COVID-19 Pandemic etc.)."
With the Brexit and the rising populism in many countries of EU, partly caused by massive migration flow to EU countries and partly because of the widening gap between rich and poor, EU could, in worst situation, be opting for disintegration. Together with the weakening of the liberal world order the voices over "Decline of the West" could be heard. What will be the influence of this geopolitical tendency in Japan? We will be examining possible negative impact of this and thinking how this trend could be reversed. The role of Japan and the EU/European countries to cope with the division of the world or decoupling of the US and China, will also be discussed.

第9回:
Nov.19 "The United Nations at crossroad: its 76 years history and the possibilities and limitations of the UN"
The UN has not been functioning well for a long time as the UN Charter envisages. This being the case because of the Cold War in the past and due to the self-centered behavior of the 5 Permanent Members(P5) of the UN Security Council for many years. Taking examples of Ukraine, Syria, Iran and the disarmament issues, particularly nuclear disarmament, the Security Council has not been a main actor when strategic interests of the P5 and 5 Nuclear Weapon countries are at stake. This has also been the case in such field of non- military nature as climate change (Paris Agreement) or Pandemic of Coronavirus. We have, however a promising UN initiative like SDGs. In this class we will be examining why the UN and Multilateralismus are not functioning well particularly in the maintenance of international peace and security and discussing what must be done.

第10回:
Nov.26 "The reform of the Security Council and the UN diplomacy of Japan: Can UN be changed?"
The key to the UN's role as a collective security system to maintain international peace and security is in the hand of the Security Council and its five permanent members(P5). However, the Security Council has not always complied with this request and the reform was called for over the years. After the demise of the Cold War, Japan embarked on the reform course and started a new campaign in 1992. Japan, Germany, Brazil, and India created a Draft Resolution (G4 Resolution) for the reform of the Security Council in 2005. However, after hectic negotiations in the General Assembly, G4 was obliged to abandon to put this draft resolution for voting. Since then, the negotiations have been conducted every year in the GA, but it is going nowhere. What are the key issues and why the negotiations stagnate? We will be examining this extremely complicated political issue in the class and discussing how the member countries are able to cut the Gordian's Knot.
